message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s gestational age and positive Nitrazine test suggest preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM), which can increase the risk of preterm delivery and neonatal morbidity and mortality. Administration of betamethasone can help to mature the fetal lungs and decrease the risk of respiratory distress syndrome. Ampicillin is given to reduce infection risk. Cesarean section is not indicated at this time, as the fetal heart rate is reactive and there are uterine contractions, indicating that labor may progress spontaneously. Amnioinfusion may be considered in the setting of variable decelerations or umbilical cord compression, but is not necessary in this case. Induction of labor may be considered if there is evidence of fetal compromise, but is not indicated in the absence of an obstetric indication.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is at 32 weeks' gestation, and the clear fluid in the cervical canal, positive Nitrazine test, and uterine contractions suggest preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM). The most appropriate next step in management is to administer betamethasone and ampicillin, as it has been shown to decrease neonatal morbidity and mortality in the setting of preterm delivery after PPROM. Option A, B, and D may be appropriate in certain situations, but are not the most appropriate next step in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The positive Nitrazine test and clear fluid in the cervical canal suggest rupture of membranes. Indomethacin is given to prolong pregnancy and reduce the risk of intraventricular hemorrhage in the fetus. Betamethasone and ampicillin are given for fetal lung maturity and to prevent group B streptococcal infection, respectively. Proceeding with cesarean section or induction of labor is not indicated at this point. Option (C), administering betamethasone and ampicillin, is the most appropriate next step in management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is at preterm labor with ruptured membranes and positive nitrazine test. Administration of betamethasone and ampicillin is the most appropriate next step in management. Cesarean section or induction of labor is not indicated at this time. Amnioinfusion may be considered in case of variable decelerations or compression of the umbilical cord.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM) and treatment with betamethasone and ampicillin is indicated to improve fetal lung maturity and prevent infection. Cesarean section is not indicated unless there is fetal distress, and induction of labor may increase the risk of infection. Amnioinfusion may be considered in cases of oligohydramnios but is not the first-line treatment for PPROM.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden leakage of clear vaginal fluid, positive nitrazine testing, and uterine contractions indicate preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM). Indomethacin may delay delivery, but antibiotics and betamethasone should be administered to decrease the risk of infection and improve fetal lung maturity. Cesarean section or induction of labor should not be performed immediately as the patient is only 32 weeks pregnant. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is to administer betamethasone and ampicillin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has premature rupture of membranes (PROM) and positive nitrazine test, indicating rupture of membranes. Tocometry also shows uterine contractions. Administration of betamethasone is indicated to enhance fetal lung maturity. Ampicillin is also given to cover for group B Streptococcus. Proceeding with cesarean section is not indicated unless there are other obstetric indications. Induction of labor may increase the risk of infection, and amnioinfusion has not been found to improve outcomes in cases of PROM.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM) at 32 weeks' gestation. In this case, the most appropriate next step is to administer betamethasone to accelerate fetal lung maturation and ampicillin to prevent infection. Cesarean section is not necessary unless there is a complication such as fetal distress. Amnioinfusion may help prevent infection but does not affect fetal lung maturation. Induction of labor may increase the risk of infection and is not recommended unless there is a complication.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM) at 32 weeks gestation with positive nitrazine testing. Administration of betamethasone is appropriate to enhance fetal lung maturity in the event of premature delivery. Ampicillin is a choice for prophylaxis against group B streptococci. Proceeding with induction of labor or cesarean section may be reserved when the patient or fetus is unstable or there is a risk of placental abruption. Amnioinfusion is not indicated in this case. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is to administer betamethasone and ampicillin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The situation might suggest premature rupture of membranes, and positive nitrazine testing confirms it. The next step is to administer betamethasone to prevent respiratory distress syndrome in the infant and ampicillin to prevent group B streptococcal infection. Since the fetal heart rate is reactive and the patient is only at 32 weeks' gestation, delivery can be delayed to allow for further fetal development. Therefore, option (C) is the most appropriate next step in management.
